hints_html: Start by finding the x-intercept(s). Then drawing the asymptote, intercepts and minimum should be a good start to drawing the entire graph.
hints_latex:
Start by finding the x-intercept(s). Then drawing the asymptote,
intercepts and minimum should be a good start to drawing the entire
graph.
hints_raw: Start by finding the x-intercept(s).  Then drawing the asymptote, intercepts and minimum should be a good start to drawing the entire graph.
question: 6 (f)
sols_html:
Before assembling the graph, we will calculate the x-intercepts, found by setting the original function equal to zero and solving for x.

\(2x^{3/5} + 3x^{-2/5} = 0\)

Factoring out \(x^{-2/5}\) gives:

\(x^{-2/5}(2x + 3) = 0\)

So there is an x-intercept at \(x = -3/2\)

To draw the graph, we will start by plotting the vertical asymptote at x = 0 and various points: the x-intercept at \((-3/2, 0)\), the minimum at \(x=1\) and the inflection point at \(x = 7/2\). Because the question asks for the y-coordinate of the minimum (from part b), we plug x = 1 into f(x) to get:

\(f(1) = 2(1)^{3/5} + 3(1)^{-2/5} = 2 + 3 = 5\)

So our minimum will be the point \((1,5)\). All this gives a picture that looks like this:

Using information from part a) about the intervals of increase and decrease, we know the graph should roughly look like this:

Finally, using part c), we know the function is concave up for \(x < 7/2\) and concave down otherwise, which leads us to the final graph:
sols_latex:
Before assembling the graph, we will calculate the x-intercepts, found
by setting the original function equal to zero and solving for \emph{x}.

$2x^{3/5} + 3x^{-2/5} = 0$

Factoring out $x^{-2/5}$ gives:

$x^{-2/5}(2x + 3) = 0$

So there is an x-intercept at $x = -3/2$

To draw the graph, we will start by plotting the vertical asymptote at
\emph{x = 0} and various points: the x-intercept at $(-3/2, 0)$, the
minimum at $x=1$ and the inflection point at $x = 7/2$. Because the
question asks for the y-coordinate of the minimum (from part b), we plug
\emph{x = 1} into \emph{f(x)} to get:

$f(1) = 2(1)^{3/5} + 3(1)^{-2/5} = 2 + 3 = 5$

So our minimum will be the point $(1,5)$. All this gives a picture that
looks like this:

\includegraphics[width=0.5\textwidth]{../json_data/MATH100/December_2012/MER_Math_100_December_2012_Question_6f_alternative.jpg}

Using information from part a) about the intervals of increase and
decrease, we know the graph should roughly look like this:

\includegraphics[width=0.5\textwidth]{../json_data/MATH100/December_2012/MER_Math100_December_2012_Question_6_part_b.jpg}

Finally, using part c), we know the function is concave up for $x < 7/2$
and concave down otherwise, which leads us to the final graph:

\includegraphics[width=0.5\textwidth]{../json_data/MATH100/December_2012/MER_Math100_December_2012_Question_6_part_c.jpg}
sols_raw:
Before assembling the graph, we will calculate the x-intercepts, found by setting the original function equal to zero and solving for ''x''.  

<math>2x^{3/5} + 3x^{-2/5} = 0</math>

Factoring out <math>x^{-2/5}</math> gives:

<math>x^{-2/5}(2x + 3) = 0</math>

So there is an x-intercept at <math>x = -3/2</math>

To draw the graph, we will start by plotting the vertical asymptote at ''x = 0'' and various points: the x-intercept at <math>(-3/2, 0)</math>, the minimum at <math>x=1</math> and the inflection point at <math>x = 7/2</math>.  Because the question asks for the y-coordinate of the minimum (from part b), we plug ''x = 1'' into ''f(x)'' to get:

<math>f(1) = 2(1)^{3/5} + 3(1)^{-2/5} = 2 + 3 = 5</math>

So our minimum will be the point <math>(1,5)</math>.  All this gives a picture that looks like this: 

[[File:MER Math 100 December 2012 Question 6f alternative.jpg]]
<!--[[File:MER Math100 December 2012 Question 6 part a.jpg]]-->

Using information from part a) about the intervals of increase and decrease, we know the graph should roughly look like this: 

[[File:MER Math100 December 2012 Question 6 part b.jpg]]

Finally, using part c), we know the function is concave up for <math>x < 7/2</math> and concave down otherwise, which leads us to the final graph: 

[[File:MER Math100 December 2012 Question 6 part c.jpg]]
statement_html:
Full-Solution Problems. In questions 5-11, justify your answers and show all your work. If a box is provided, write your final answer there. Unless otherwise indicated, simplification of numerical answers is required in these questions.

6. Let \(f(x) = 2x^{3/5} + 3x^{-2/5}\). Note that the domain of \(f\) is the set of all nonzero real numbers; for example, \(f(-1) = -2 + 3 = 1\).

(f) Sketch the graph of \(y = f(x)\), exhibiting all features in parts (a) - (e) and showing the y-coordinates of any points you found in part (b) (you do not need to include the y-coordinates of inflection points). Also, indicate the coordinates of all x-intercepts.
statement_latex:
\textbf{Full-Solution Problems}. In questions 5-11, justify your answers
and \textbf{show all your work}. If a box is provided, write your final
answer there. \textbf{Unless otherwise indicated, simplification of
numerical answers is required in these questions.}

6. Let $f(x) = 2x^{3/5} + 3x^{-2/5}$. Note that the domain of $f$ is the
set of all nonzero real numbers; for example, $f(-1) = -2 + 3 = 1$.

(f) Sketch the graph of $y = f(x)$, exhibiting all features in parts (a)
- (e) and showing the \emph{y}-coordinates of any points you found in
part (b) (you do not need to include the \emph{y}-coordinates of
inflection points). Also, indicate the coordinates of all
\emph{x}-intercepts.
statement_raw:
'''Full-Solution Problems'''. In questions 5-11, justify your answers and '''show all your work'''. If a box is provided, write your final answer there. '''Unless otherwise indicated, simplification of numerical answers is required in these  questions.'''

6. Let <math>f(x) = 2x^{3/5} + 3x^{-2/5}</math>. Note that the domain of &fnof; is the set of all nonzero real numbers; for example, <math>f(-1) = -2 + 3 = 1</math>.

(f) Sketch the graph of <math>y = f(x)</math>, exhibiting all features in parts (a) - (e) and showing the ''y''-coordinates of any points you found in part (b) (you do not need to include the ''y''-coordinates of inflection points). Also, indicate the coordinates of all ''x''-intercepts.
